Award.AwardTitle: High-Resolution Morphological Control of Silicon Nanowires for Bottom-Up Photonics and Plasmonics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: This project aims to develop a bottom-up method for high-resolution control of silicon nanowire morphology. Semiconductor nanowires have traditionally been limited to cylindrical, axially symmetric structures, yet many new technological applications for nanowires could be enabled with a method to break the axial symmetry and produce well-controlled shapes along the nanowire axis. In pursuit of this goal, this research project investigates fundamental aspects of in-situ chemical doping of silicon nanowires and doping-dependent wet-chemical etching processes. The research is expected to yield fundamental insights into the incorporation of dopants during both vapor-liquid-solid and vapor-solid-solid nanowire growth processes. By systematically exploring the dependence of wet-chemical etch rates on nanowire doping, this project is also expected to enable the synthesis of nanowires in which the axial morphology is modulated on length scales ranging from a few nanometers to several micrometers. The optical absorption and scattering characteristics of the morphologically-controlled nanowires are studied through a combination of experiment and finite-element simulations to determine their potential technological application in the areas of nanophotonics and plasmonics.

Non-technical Description: Most well-developed semiconductor technologies require the patterning of materials on a microscopic scale. Semiconductor nanowires often lack the nanometer-scale patterning capability, which is necessary for many applications. This project aims to develop a simple chemical method to encode high-resolution patterns into nanowires composed of silicon. The results from this project are expected to substantially expand our fundamental understanding of nanowire growth processes. The optical properties of the wires are studied to determine their potential application for technologies that use light for information processing and computing applications. This project is integrated into educational and outreach activities involving middle-school through graduate-level students. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in the research on a year-round basis are trained in a cross-disciplinary environment that bridges concepts from chemistry, engineering, physics, and materials science. Through a summer outreach program, middle- and high-school students from traditionally underrepresented groups experience hands-on research emphasizing original concepts and discovery. The overall project is designed to foster collaboration between students with a diverse range of backgrounds using concepts and techniques derived from all areas of the physical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Silicon is the second most abundant element in the earth’s crust and is a widely used semiconductor for technologies ranging from solar cells to smart phones. However, technological applications of silicon require precise control over the material in order to alter its electronic and optical properties. In this project, we developed a new method to control the shape, or morphology, of silicon nanowires. This process is termed ENGRAVE, which stands for Encoded Nanowire GRowth and Appearance through VLS and Etching. In the ENGRAVE process, we first grow long and tubular silicon crystals (nanowires) that are extremely small, measuring only tens of nanometers in diameter. Second, we precisely remove material along the length of the nanowire to reveal precise shapes. Conceptually, the ENGRAVE method acts like a nanoscale lathe to create very precise nanostructures. Shapes are encoded in the nanowires by continuously changing the composition of the silicon nanowire crystals. In this project, we explored the fundamental mechanisms related to the ENGRAVE process and determined that the spatial resolution was better than 5 nanometers, and in some cases as small as 2 nanometers, which is sufficiently small to make the method useful for a wide-range of electronic and optical technologies. For instance, we showed that the method can be used to continuously change the color of the nanowires, an effect that could be used for color displays and other applications. In addition, we showed that small constrictions in the nanowires can be used to alter current flow, which could be the basis for computer memory. Most importantly, this project highlighted the fundamental mechanisms and limitations for the ENGRAVE process and developed it as a new tool for designing the electronic and optical properties of silicon through the precise control of shape. In addition, we developed a method to weld separate nanowires together, and the process, when coupled with the ENGRAVE method, provides a route to further design silicon for various technologies.


The results of this project have been widely disseminated, including more than 14 publications in high-impact peer-reviewed journals and more than 20 presentations at local, national, and international conferences. The project has resulted in the training of numerous high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students. High-school students have continued on to undergraduate studies in the sciences, undergraduate students have continued on to PhD programs in the sciences, and graduate students have moved on to both academic and industry positions. In addition, we have performed numerous outreach events, including an annual booth at the UNC Chapel Hill Science Exposition, demonstrations in elementary-school classrooms, and orientation and science-day events for numerous local organizations.
